News.title: Prince Harry and Meghan comfort cancer patients and their families on emotional visit
News.content:
Prince Harry and Meghan comfort cancer patients and their families on emotional visit

Prince Harry and Meghan paid an emotional visit to the King Hussein Cancer Centre, Jordan's leading cancer hospital, in the last engagement of their whirlwind trip to the country

View 5 Images Harry and Meghan at the King Hussein cancer centre today (Image: World Health Organisation via Ge)

Prince Harry and Meghan comforted young cancer patients and their emotional families as they heard about their fights against the disease. The Duchess of Sussex was seen holding hands with one mother, rubbing her arm as she broke down while telling of her son's battle with leukaemia during a visit to Jordan’s leading cancer hospital on Harry and Meghan's two-day trip to the Middle Eastern country.

‌



And Harry embraced a young girl after they bonded over her tales of learning English from Peppa Pig cartoons hours before her next chemotherapy session. The visit to the King Hussein Cancer Centre was the final event in a busy two-day trip to Jordan for the Sussexes, who travelled to learn more about the humanitarian effort to support the health and well-being of Syrians and Palestinians who have sought sanctuary in Jordan.

‌



Prince Harry and Meghan Markle share emotional messages of support during trip to Jordan READ MORE :

5 View 5 Images Meghan holds hands with the tearful mother of a cancer patient (Image: PA) 5 View 5 Images Harry and Meghan offer hugs to families (Image: PA)

‌



Meghan showed empathy with Huda Ramadan Alrhawjara, hugging the mother from Gaza after she described how her schoolboy son Mohammad had a recurrence of leukaemia during the recent Israeli conflict against Hamas in the Gaza Strip.

Through tears, Mrs Alrhawjara, who has spent 18 months in Jordan with her son for his treatment, said in Arabic: “It doesn’t matter if it takes four years, what matters is to have him healthy.”

The mother and son were among a group of young Palestinians from Gaza being treated at the cancer centre and invited to meet the duke and duchess.

‌



Mrs Alrhawjara, who was hugged again by Meghan before she left and also Harry, said: “I’m really happy that the prince and his wife are really on the side of the families, and that they came to hear our stories, it shows their humanity.” The Sussexes began their tour of the cancer centre by meeting young patients in a play area that puts them at ease before treatment – and allows the youngsters to be children.

View 5 Images Harry listens to the story of one young cancer sufferer (Image: World Health Organisation via Ge)

Harry quickly made friends with Sham, a 13-year-old girl from Syria waiting for a chemotherapy session for leukaemia later that day, and he was impressed by her English learnt through a relative, watching movies and Peppa Pig cartoons.

‌



It came as earlier today, Harry urged a group of recovered addicts to go back to their communities and help others, telling them: “There’s no shame in having an addiction.”

He and Meghan listened intently as a group of men described the emotional toll of substance abuse and the support they have received from Jordan’s National Centre for Rehabilitation of Addicts.

After chatting to one man who was addicted to drugs but is now a mentor at the centre, Harry said: “I want you guys to know there’s no shame in having an addiction, it stems from something else, which is an emotional pain – you’re very, very brave to come here into hospital.

‌



View 5 Images Harry and Meghan are shown around the King Hussein cancer centre in Jordan (Image: World Health Organisation via Ge)

“Now what you need to do is use this experience and go back into your communities and help other people who are in a similar situation.” During the visit, the couple were invited to write messages of support along with a World Health Organisation delegation they were travelling with, including its director-general Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesu, who invited the couple to Jordan.

Harry’s message on a sticky-note read: “It’s ok to not be ok. Trust each other. Congratulations on your recovery. Now share your courage and experience.”

‌



The couple had earlier began their final day of their trip to Jordan, hearing about the World Central Kitchen’s huge logistical task of feeding a million Palestinians in Gaza.

Harry and Meghan chatted via video call with a distribution leader at one of the organisation’s six field kitchens in Gaza, producing daily hot meals for around 60 per cent of the population.

Article continues below

Wadhah Hubaishi, the organisation’s response director for the Middle East and North Africa, told the couple that ochre and rice was the meal for Thursday.

He said their mantra was “food with smiles” provided by Gazans for Gazans and highlighted the need for food by telling the couple the touching story of a boy who had never seen a banana. “A three-year-old ate a banana and asked his father ‘can I eat the peel’,” he said.

News.title: King Charles tries out missile launcher that shoots down enemy drones
News.content:
King Charles tries out missile launcher that shoots down enemy drones

The King got to handle an air defence missile launcher as he paid a visit to Baker Barracks on Thorney Island in Hampshire to visit the 7th Air Defence Group Royal Artillery units

View 4 Images The handles a missile launcher on a visit to Baker Barracks in Hampshire today (Image: PA)

The King tried out handling an air defence missile launcher on a visit to an army barracks - with troops saying he would pass the test of using the machinery. Charles was able to look through the aiming unit of the launcher as soldiers huddled with him under a camouflage net with drones flying overhead at Baker Barracks on Thorney Island in Hampshire today.

‌



The launcher when fired by an operator would take approximately four seconds to destroy an enemy target. Lieutenant Colonel Maarten Magee said it was an “absolute privilege” to show the King the kit, used to shoot down enemy threats such as drones and helicopters, and that he got “a flavour of what we are facing”.

‌



King Charles puts on united front with Firm as Andrew arrest fallout continues READ MORE :

Kate Middleton beams as she gazes at William on special trip to mark poignant day READ MORE :

View 4 Images Charles was able to look through the aiming unit of the launcher as soldiers huddled with him under a camouflage net (Image: PA)

‌



He added the King was more interested in how the forces were dealing with modern threats, and he described the visit as a “once-in-a-lifetime experience for the regiment and the island to see him”.

Charles handled the weaponry as he made his first visit to the 7th Air Defence Group Royal Artillery units at the military site in his role of Captain General of the Royal Regiment of Artillery, also known as the Gunners. He arrived shortly after 1pm by helicopter, wearing a suit and regimental tie and pin, and was greeted by a 21-gun salute by the 1st Regiment Royal Horse Artillery, who fired seven rounds each.

Families, nursery and school children at the barracks also lined up to watch the military welcome. Charles spoke to military service personnel based in Saudi Arabia, Estonia, Cyprus and the Falklands via video link in the Junior Ranks’ Restaurant, which he officially opened as their families watched.

‌



View 4 Images The King chats to members of the 7th Air Defence Group Royal Artillery (Image: PA)

Some of the troops abroad said they were looking forward to coming home soon, to which Charles said: “It won’t be long hopefully.” The daughter of Sergeant Jack Harding based in the Falkands, Poppy, aged five, handed the King a letter after he spoke to the overseas soldiers.

Poppy’s mother and Sergeant Harding’s wife, Charley Harding, said the letter said how incredible the opportunity is and how the children would love a reply to add to their memory boxes. She added: “And that actually the royal family are a great support to the military.

‌



“It’s just nice that obviously with our husbands away and other family members, to have him come down and recognise that us as families do struggle as well, just show that extra support. I mean, it’s great.”

View 4 Images Families, nursery and school children at the barracks also lined up to watch the military welcome (Image: Getty Images)

The 28-year-old teaching assistant said that it is hard for the children with their father away, and that “they’ve very resilient” with three deployments during Poppy’s lifetime, and two for her younger son Freddie, aged three.

‌



Meanwhile, Charles spoke to Jade McGowan, whose husband Andrew McGowan is currently based in Cyprus and does not have a date to come home yet. The King asked about her nearly eight-month-old twins, Hamish and Brodie, and of her husband being away she said: “It’s hard, we are doing what we can.”

Speaking afterwards the 36-year-old said the King was “really friendly” and him meeting the families was “amazing”, adding: “It makes it a bit easier, doesn’t, it to know that you’re not alone and that don’t feel that you are alone, because there is so much support.”

Article continues below

The Gunners was founded in 1716 and earned the Battle Honour Ubique meaning everywhere, as it is believed the regiment has served in every conflict the British Army has been involved with.

The King became the ceremonial head of the Royal Artillery on August 11 2023, in a role first taken by King George VI in 1947, followed by Queen Elizabeth II in 1952. The Royal Artillery is made up of 14 regular regiments and seven reserve regiments.

News.title: UK snow maps reveal -4C 'Beast from the East' as cities including London buried
News.content:
UK snow maps reveal -4C 'Beast from the East' as cities including London buried

Weather forecasting maps suggest cold air masses will soon move over the UK from the east and bring snow to several major cities including London and Birmingham

View 6 Images Cold air masses will drift from east to west and impact the UK, maps suggest (Image: WX CHARTS)

A ‘Beast from the East’ snowstorm looks set to bring flurries right across the UK in just a few days’ time - with several major cities in the firing line.

‌



The GFS weather model shows masses of cold air forming over Europe on March 12. These masses are tracked to move from east to west, bringing chilly conditions and snow to our shores.

‌



Maps first show snow falling in southern parts of England and Wales at around 9pm, with London set to see some of the white stuff. The snow is then tracked to move northward.

‌



By 6am on March 13, snow is shown falling across most of Wales, southern England, the Midlands and a huge swathe of northern England. Birmingham and Manchester could both see snow.

View 6 Images Snow is expected to fall in London on March 12 (Image: WX CHARTS)

Met Office 10-day weather forecast names exactly where in UK faces snow READ MORE :

Snow maps reveal rare March blizzard to bury cities in England and Scotland READ MORE :

Ensure our latest headlines always appear at the top of your Google Search by making us a Preferred Source. Click here to activate or add us as your Preferred Source in your Google search settings.

‌



Snow will have reached Northern Ireland and Scotland by midday, the GFS weather model suggests. The heaviest snow is expected to fall over hills in northern England.

Snow coverage maps reveal almost all of England and Wales will have snow settled on the ground by midday. While temperature maps suggest the mercury could drop as low as -4C in southern England.

View 6 Images Snow is expected to move northward up the UK (Image: WX CHARTS)

‌



Wales, Northern Ireland, Scotland and northern parts of England could see temperatures as low as -2C. The Midlands could drop as low as -1C.

BBC Weather also suggests some chilly weather could come in March. Although, BBC forecasters say it is too early to known for sure just how cold conditions will turn.

View 6 Images Several major cities including Manchester are facing flurries (Image: WX CHARTS)

‌



The BBC forecast for March 9 to 22 states: "Until middle of March, it is most likely that the UK will find itself situated between European high pressure and Atlantic low pressure and frontal systems. Occasional rain and brisk winds are likely, although indications are for near average precipitation amounts for the period as a whole.

"Milder than average conditions are expected overall, or at least near seasonal. There is a slight possibility that high pressure could build at higher latitudes in the second half of March, which would bring a chance of some chiller outbreaks, but at the moment that's rather speculative and no significant early spring cold is looking likely."

View 6 Images Snow is expected to settle across a massive swathe of the country (Image: WX CHARTS)

‌



The Met Office says some snow could fall next month. Its forecast for March 3 to 12 states: "Much of this period looks like being largely dominated by high pressure, especially towards the south or southeast of the UK.

"This will mean many places seeing plenty of dry weather with variable cloud amounts and some sunshine, the best of this towards the south or southeast, but perhaps with some fog overnight.

View 6 Images Temperatures could drop as low as -4C (Image: WX CHARTS)

Article continues below

"However, frontal systems are still likely to affect the north and west of the UK at times though, maybe also briefly affecting other parts, bringing some rain and strong winds, and perhaps a little snow to the high ground in the north. Temperatures will be near or above normal, although patchy overnight frost is still likely at times."
